info.text 1:
In the stunning green hills of Northern Iran, one cemetery is covered in headstones distinctly resembling male and female genitalia. Some are cylindrical and capped, while others are paired and rounded. All told, the cemetery has a total of 600 monuments to sex organs sprawling across the vibrant landscape. 
Khalid Nabi Cemetery is a little-known place in 90 km northeast of the city of Gonbad-e kavous. Next to this cemetery, there exists a mosque, a few rooms, a cistern, which is called Lari with native people, and some other buildings.
info.text 2:
Located in the highlands and mountainous areas of Golestan province, and surrounded by the countryside's spectacular landscapes, this area is an important tourist attraction in the north of the country.  
It is mainly situated on a mountain ridge about 1 km distance from the mausoleum called "Khaled Nabi" who according to oral tradition of the Yomut Turkomans was a pre-Islamic prophet and whose mausoleum is visited by them for pilgrimage together with the neighbouring one of Ata Chofun ("Father Shepherd"), his son-in-law. The cemetery was visited in 1979 and 1980 by the archeologist David Stronach. He found over 600 standing stones which are spread out in several locations. About half of them are on the ridge which he calls "High Plateau" South and south-east of that are small groups of stones on several other ridges and hillocks. At some distance, there is another group of perhaps 150 stones distributed over a wide area on the mountain's south side.

info.text 1: This obelisk in Heliopolis is the oldest obelisk among all the standing obelisks worldwide. This 20.7 m high obelisk was erected by Senusret I (Middle Kingdom the 12th Dynasty, Reigned 20 Century BC). Although this has been standing almost 4000 years in this place, but due to the rise of groundwater level the pedestal and the bottom of obelisk became immersed in water, the construction of raising the obelisk was done in the 1970s by Krupp of Germany. Regarding the inscriptions of this obelisk, they are the same for all 4 sides: the Horus name, coronation name, and birth name of Senusret I.
info.text 2:
Heliopolis was a major city of ancient Egypt. It was the capital of the 13th or Heliopolite Nome of Lower Egypt and a major religious center. It is now located in Ayn Shams, a northeastern district of Cairo.  
Heliopolis was one of the oldest cities of ancient Egypt, occupied since prehistoric Egypt. It greatly expanded under the Old and Middle Kingdoms but is today mostly destroyed, its temples and other buildings having been scavenged for the construction of medieval Cairo. Most information about the ancient city comes from surviving records.  
The major surviving remnant of Heliopolis is the obelisk of the Temple of Ra-Atum erected by Senusret I of Dynasty XII. It still stands in its original position, now within Al-Masalla in El Matareya, Cairo. The 21 m (69 ft) high red granite obelisk weighs 120 tons (240,000 lbs). Dedicated to Ra-Atum, the Sun deity and, by that, the most important male representation, being considered one of the first manifestations of Phallic Culture.

info.text 1: Min is an Egyptian deity of ancient Egypt, whose worship originated in the Predynastic period (4th millennium BC). He was depicted in various forms, but most frequently with a human appearance, with an erect penis held in his right hand and his left hand raised (possibly to suggest penetration or as a threatening gesture towards his enemies), holding a flail. He was the god of fertility, reproduction, the harvest, the male principle, and virility.
info.text 2:
As the god of male sexual potency, Min was especially honored during the pharaoh's coronation in the New Kingdom, a ceremony during which it seems the sovereign had to scatter his own seed. It is believed that this action was symbolized by the scattering of plant seeds, but there are controversial theories suggesting that the pharaoh had to demonstrate his ability to ejaculate, thus ensuring the annual flooding of the Nile, which was crucial for Egypt's prosperity. When the king fathered an heir, he was compared to Min. 
He was also a lunar god, invoked in this aspect with the epithet Protector of the Moon. The last days of the lunar calendar were sacred to him, and in the Ptolemaic period, the fifth month of the year was even dedicated to him.

info.text 1:
Kokopelli is a fertility deity, usually depicted as a humpbacked flute player (often with feathers or antenna-like protrusions on his head), who is venerated by some Native American cultures in the Southwestern United States. Like most fertility deities, Kokopelli presides over both childbirth and agriculture. He is also a trickster god and represents the spirit of music. 
Kokopelli has been revered since at least the time of the Hohokam, Yuman, and Ancestral Puebloan peoples. The first known images of him appear on Hohokam pottery dated to sometime between 750 and 850 AD.
info.text 2:
Among the Hopi, Kokopelli carries unborn children on his back and distributes them to women; for this reason, young girls often fear him. He often takes part in rituals relating to marriage, and Kokopelli himself is sometimes depicted with a consort, a woman called Kokopelmimi by the Hopi. It is said that Kokopelli can be seen on the full and waning moon, much like the "man" or the "rabbit" on the moon." 
In his domain over agriculture, Kokopelli's flute-playing chases away the winter and brings about spring. Many tribes, such as the Zuni, also associate Kokopelli with the rains. He frequently appears with Paiyatamu, another flutist, in depictions of maize-grinding ceremonies. Some tribes say he carries seeds and babies on his back.

info.text 1: In Greek religion, Priapus was a god of animal and vegetable fertility whose originally Asian cult started in the Hellespontine regions, centring especially on Lampsacus. He was represented in a caricature of the human form, grotesquely misshapen, with an enormous phallus. The ass was sacrificed in his honor, probably because the ass symbolized lecherousness and was associated with the god's sexual potency. The statue found in Ephesus and dated to the 2nd century AD is a testimony of that.
info.text 2:
Priapus' iconic attribute was his priapism (permanently erect penis); he probably absorbed some pre-existing ithyphallic deities as his cult developed. Statues of Priapus were common in ancient Greece and Rome, standing in gardens. The Athenians often conflated Priapus with Hermes, the god of boundaries, and depicted a hybrid deity with a winged helmet, sandals, and huge erection.  
Outside his "home" region in Asia Minor, Priapus was regarded as something of a joke by urban dwellers. However, he played a more important role in the countryside, where he was seen as a guardian deity. He was regarded as the patron god of sailors and fishermen and others in need of good luck, and his presence was believed to avert the evil eye. Priapus does not appear to have had an organized cult and was mostly worshiped in gardens or homes, though there are attestations of temples dedicated to the god.

info.text 1: Poenulus, also called The Little Carthaginian or The Little Punic Man, is a Latin comedic play for the early Roman theatre by Titus Maccius Plautus, probably written between 195 and 189 BC. Plautus' comedies are mostly adapted from Greek models for a Roman audience and are often based directly on the works of the Greek playwrights. He reworked the Greek texts to give them a flavor that would appeal to the local Roman audiences. They are the earliest surviving intact works in Latin literature.
info.text 2:
Plautus plays, as all the Roman Comedies adapted from Greek Theater, are marked for the removal of the previously prominent role of the chorus. Then, the phallic elements are spread in the dialogues.  
In Plautus' Poenulus, phallic elements are central to the play's humor and thematic content. The phallic amulet symbolizes protection and fertility, a common Roman belief, and is used humorously by the characters. The phallic lamp adds to the comedic tone through its shape and the associated superstitions. Additionally, the phallic dance performed by slaves aligns with Roman fertility rites and serves as a source of humor. Sexual innuendos and jokes about virility also play a significant role, reflecting the cultural importance of the phallus in Roman entertainment and daily life.

info.text 1: This fresco of the Roman god Priapus was found in the House of the Vettii, Regio VI, Pompeii, and dates back to I century AD. The building and the artworks it contained were significantly damaged as a consequence of the Vesuvio's eruption of 79 BC, but excavation works held between 1894 and 1895 brought back this fresco, devoted to the patron of the House. This portrayal of the god shares with other iconographic evidence the ithyphallic representation of the deity, while the basket of fruits on the ground stresses the connection between the deity and fertility.
info.text 2:
The fresco found in the House of the Vettii summarizes some of Priapus' primary meanings. The traditional display of the phallus, where the deity is weighing against a bag of gold, suggests its main significance as a symbol of virility, and thus power that stems from domination over others.  
For this reason, Priapus was also considered a guardian of property, with his huge organ used as a weapon against thieves. There are several examples of both anthropomorphic and non-anthropomorphic phallic representations displayed on land boundaries or thresholds, like in the case of the House of the Vettii, where the fresco portraying the god is placed right at the entrance of the building.  
However, from the very beginning of the cult of Priapus, the deity is also associated with fertility: in this regard, the god is a patron of agriculture, but also a sort of lucky charm for young males approaching adulthood.

itemMeta.conservation location: House of the Vettii, Pompeii, Italy

info.text 1: This marble sculpture of Priapus' head dates to the Augustean era, thus its realization can be placed somewhere around the last thirty years of I century BC and the first quarter of I century AD. The item displays a rich hairstyle and a thoroughly drawn beard, making it a particularly interesting artwork from an ornamental perspective. The sculpture is currently preserved by Museo di Scultura Antica Giovanni Barracco in Rome.
info.text 2: The iconography of Priapus' head seems to be consistent across representations of the deity originated from different areas, starting from Lampsacus, where the god is already portrayed as a bearded man. In some way, this representation is connected to the one usually typical of satyrs, minor deities which, like Dionysus and Priapus, were related to the cult of fertility. Like Priapus, satyrs often tried to seduce nymphs and mortal women alike, with little success. Despite the similarities, the monstruosity and deformity of the satyrs were often immediately reflected in their faces and, at least at the earliest stages, they were represented with animalistic attributes, while Priapus' grotesque appearance is mostly related to his excessive phallus, explained by the myth as a punishment from Hera, due to her gealousy towards Aphrodite, either for her adulterous relationship with Zeus or for her success in the eyes of Paris.

info.text 1: The date of creation of the artwork is unknown, but supposedly close to the other Pompeiian fresco, e.g. somewhere along I century AD. The fresco is severely damaged, but it is possible to identify the figure of Priapus with his characteristic attributes.
info.text 2: The fresco was discovered at the entrance of a prestigious residence on Via del Vesuvio. The position of the fresco right at the entrance of the house makes it a powerful apotropaic symbol, able to fight the evil eye and to bring good fortune, as confirmed by the other objects painted next to the deity: a bag of coins, along with a plate with fruit and vegetables placed at the god's feet.

info.text 1: This bronze sculpture dates back to I century AD. The item is an example of tintinnabulum, a widespread object in ancient Rome. The tintinnabulum was a wind chime with several little bells connected to one main structure, and, in most cases, was represented as a fascinum - e.g. a phallus - sometimes winged or legged. This is, however, an anthropomorphic example of tintinnabulum, which conflates the gods Priapus, with the usual ithyphallic depiction, and Mercury, who was believed to be the son or father of the deity in some variants of the myth.
info.text 2: The merging of Hermes - which is the Greek equivalent of Mercury - and Priapus was already popular between Athenians and, evidently, outlived up to Roman times. In this particular example, the presence of Mercury is testified by the winged helmet, which was a typical attribute of the god. As Priapus, Mercury, who was mainly associated with trade and economic prosperity, was also worshipped as a patron of boundaries in Greek and Roman mythology. The combination of these meanings explains the meaning associated to Mercury in the tintinnabulum, which was usually hung to thresholds as an amulet for both protection and prosperity, conveyed by the phallus and the bag of gold.

itemMeta.conservation location: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Italy

info.text 1: This sculptural group is a roman copy of an Hellenistic original and yet another example of the spreading of Priapus' variegated representations in II century BC Pompeii. The sculpture is peculiar for the golden decoration on Venus' body - the golden bikini - realized with gold flakes on the marble of the statue. The item shows Venus leaning on Priapus with Eros at her feet, while she attempts to untie her sandal.
info.text 2: The sculpture was originally part of the House of the Venus with the Golden Bikini - named after the statue due to its retrieval within the building in 1954 - which dates back to II century BC and was re-discovered during the excavations promoted in 1913. While the paternity of Priapus is uncertain, shifting from Dionysus, to Zeus, to Mercury, all the variants of the myth present Aphrodite/Venus as the mother of Priapus. The unfortunate aspect of the god is a punishment coming from Hera, in one version for her jealousy towards Aphrodite's victory in the contest between Hera herself, Aphrodite and Athena, in another for the relation between Zeus and the goddess of love. As explained by the director of the Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, which currently holds the work in the Secret Cabinet collection, the sculpture has a strong erotic tension, stressed by the action of untying the laces of the sandal and conveyed by the presence of figures related to love and erotism as Venus herself, Priapus and Eros.

itemMeta.conservation location: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Italy

info.text 1: This bas-relief was carved in Leptis Magna, current Lybia, and dates back to II century AD. Fascinus was a non-anthropomorphic Roman deity that took the form of the phallus alone, as suggested by the name which, among other meanings, has the one of "penis". Fascinus was believed to have apotropaic powers against evel eye, and was thereby displayed on crossroads, houses, on chariots during the celebration of a triumph, or even wore, especially by young Roman males, as an amulet protecting from diseases.
info.text 2: The presence of this kind of symbolic evidence in colonies testifies the rooting of phallic symbolism and devotion within Roman civilization. In this particular item, a legged fascinus is ejaculating into an (evil) eye, which malevolent power is further stressed by the scorpion sitting on it. These kinds of non-anthropomorphic representations were entirely Roman and recurred in a wide range of situations, that all came down to protection from evil and envy, prosperity, preservation of one's property and boundaries. Along with Fascinus, another deity was solely identified by the phallus: Mutinus Titinus, whose name comes again from colloquial words used to indicate the male sexual organ, and being a marriage deity, was strongly linked to conjugal fertility. Both Fascinus and Mutinus Titinus cults predate the spreading of the cult of Priapus, to whom they transferred their meaning and powers.

info.text 1: Phallic saints are representations of saints or local deities who are invoked for fertility. These representations are benevolent symbols of prolificacy and reproductive fruitfulness, and objects of reverence and worship especially among barren women and young girls.
info.text 2:
Saint Guerlichon (or Saint Guerluchon) was a syncretic phallic saint venerated at Bourg-Dieu near Bourges, France. Before a gradual transformation into St. Guerlichon, it was an old priapic statue that was worshiped by the surrounding people during the Roman occupation of Gaul. 
At Bourg-Dieu, there existed, during the Roman occupation of Gaul, an old priapic statue, which was worshiped by the surrounding people. The veneration in which it was held and the miracles with which it was accredited made it impolitic as well as impossible for the early missionaries and monks to remove it. 
 It was therefore allowed to remain, but gradually transformed into a saint, St. Guerlichon, which did not detract any from its former merit or reputation. Sterile women flocked to the shrine, and pilgrimages and a set number of days of devotion to this saint were in order.

info.text 1: The manuscript Plut. 33 31 contains an anthology of classical and medieval Latin authors, a testament to the most eclectic and singular cultural interests of Boccaccio, who prepared and inscribed the manuscript at different times and under various circumstances. This codex is the oldest surviving witness of the Priapea and joined the Biblioteca Laurenziana in the third quarter of the 16th century.
info.text 2: The volume includes, among other works, the Expositio sermonum antiquorum by Fulgentius, the Satirae by Persius, several texts from the Appendix Vergiliana, the Ibis and the Amores by Ovid, the Megacosmus et Microcosmus by Bernardus Silvestris, the medieval comedies Geta by Vitalis of Blois, Alda by William of Blois and Lydia by Arnulf of Orléans, a collection of maxims and various verses from the Anthologia Latina. The collection is extraordinary important because some of the lesser-known texts it contains are preserved only in this or a few other manuscripts; examples include the tetrastich in honor of Saint Miniatus, the Lamentatio Bertoldi, a scholastic cento of classical and medieval Latin quotations, and the only surviving fragment of Lovato Lovati's poem on Tristan and Isolde, otherwise unknown. Boccaccio's hand has been identified in the text and in the numerous marginal and interlinear annotations, which also bear witness to his graphic and decorative flair. The history of the codex is intertwined with that of the famous Zibaldone Laurenziano; the two manuscripts, once united, are both partly composed of palimpsest leaves from a 13th-century gradual written in Beneventan script. The codex belonged to the scholar and canon of the Florentine basilica of San Lorenzo, Antonio Petrei (1498-1570) and it joined the Biblioteca Laurenziana in the third quarter of the 16th century.

info.text 1: Lysistrata ('army disbander') is an ancient Greek comedy by Aristophanes, originally performed in classical Athens in 411 BC. It is a comic account of a woman's extraordinary mission to end the Peloponnesian War between Greek city states by denying all the men of the land any sex, which was the only thing they truly and deeply desired.
info.text 2: Lysistrata persuades the women of the warring cities to withhold sexual privileges from their husbands and lovers as a means of forcing the men to negotiate peace. This strategy, however, inflames the battle between the sexes.

items.name: Two Lovers in front of the hermes of Priapus

info.text 1: "Due amanti davanti al busto di priapo" is an oil on canvas painting. It was realized in France between the XVIII-XIX Century by the painter Louis Vincent Léon Pallière.
info.text 2: The painting shows a rare subject that may refer to the sensual arouse of two lovers. The painter belongs to the French neoclassical period and stands out for his amazing composing and drawing capability.
info.text 3:
Louis Vincent Léon Pallière was born on July 19, 1787 in Bordeaux1. A pupil of François-André Vincent at theÉcole des beaux-arts in Paris, he attempted the Prix de Rome several times: in 1805 with The Death of Demosthenes, then in 1808, 1809 - where he came second -, 1810, 1811, and finally successfully in 1812 with Ulysses and Telemachus Slaughtering the Pretenders. He stayed in Rome at the Villa Medici between 1813 and 1816, where he painted several pictures. He became friends with the painter François-Édouard Picot, with whom he worked on the decorations for the Trinité-des-Monts convent, for which he painted a Flagellation that is still in place.
He was highly acclaimed at the Salon of 1819, where several of his Roman paintings were exhibited, and was awarded a first-class medal. He also painted several large religious pictures that adorned Parisian churches: in 1812, he donated a Death of Saint Monica and a Christ on the Cross to thechurch of Saint-Eustache. In 1819, he presented a Saint Pierre guérissant le boiteux (Saint Peter Healing the Limping Man) for thechurch of Saint-Séverin (now in thechurch of Saint-Thomas-d'Aquin), and in 1820 was commissioned to paint a Délivrance de saint Pierre (Deliverance of Saint Peter) for thechurch of Saint-Pierre in Bordeaux. Left unfinished at his death, the composition was finished by his friend Picot and exhibited at the Salon of 1827.
The painter died in 1820 of a chest ailment. He had married the painter Françoise Virginie Liégeois, who after remarriage became Fanny Alaux.

info.text 1: The Ypsilanti Water Tower is a historic water tower in Ypsilanti, Michigan, United States. Today the tower is frequently joked about for its phallic shape.
info.text 2: The tower was designed by William R. Coats and built as part of an elaborate city waterworks project that began in 1889. Located on the highest point in Ypsilanti, the tower was built in 1890. It has become a well-known landmark in Ypsilanti, and due to the building's shape and location, the tower is frequently used by residents as a point for providing directions for visitors and residents.

info.text 1: The Torre Glòries, formerly known as Torre Agbar, is a 38-story skyscraper located between Avinguda Diagonal and Carrer Badajoz, near Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes, which marks the gateway to the new technological district of Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain.
info.text 2:
The Torre Glòries was designed by French architect Jean Nouvel in association with the Spanish firm b720 Fermín Vázquez Arquitectos and built by Dragados. It is located in the Poblenou neighbourhood of Barcelona and it was originally named after its owners, the Agbar Group, a holding company whose interests include the Barcelona water company Aigües de Barcelona.
The tower is 144.44 m high with a diameter of 39 m. It has a total of 50,693 m2 (545,650 sq ft), of which 30,000 m2 (320,000 sq ft) are offices, 3,210 m2 (34,600 sq ft) technical facilities, 8,132 m2 (87,530 sq ft) services, including an auditorium, and 9,132 m2 (98,300 sq ft) parking space. It cost 130 million to build.
It opened in June 2005 and was officially opened by King Juan Carlos I on 16 September 2005. It is one in a collection of high-tech architecture examples in Barcelona.
The building was owned by the multinational group Agbar, which has its corporate headquarters in the building and which takes up most of the floors, leasing the remainder. The Agbar Tower was acquired in March 2010 for 165 million euros, after reaching an agreement with its former owner, the investment group Azurelau. Azurelau had previously bought the property in mid-2007. The purchase price was not disclosed.
By 2017 it was purchased by Merlin Properties real estate group and it was renamed as Torre Glòries after the name of the adjacent square.
